awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research:   Mechanistic understanding and control of soft interfacial nanorheology from molecular simulations and nanoresolved experiments
awd_abstract_narration:
CBET 1705738/1706012
PIs: Simmons, David S./Priestly, Rodney D.

From longer-lasting and safer batteries to strong and lightweight composites for use in airplanes and automobile bodies, many of the materials that could open the door to tomorrow's technologies incorporate structure on the nanometer scale. These materials are not composed of single uniform substance.  Instead, these "nanostructured" materials consist of vast numbers of distinct alternating domains, each a thousand times smaller than the thickness of a human hair. With the proper design, these composites have the potential to combine the best properties of multiple materials into one.  However, researchers have found the performance of nanostructured materials depends not only on the composition of the nanoscale domains, but also on the interfaces between the domains.  The behavior of these interfaces, which are too small to characterize directly with current tools, remains unknown. This collaborative award will support experiments and computer simulations of molecular motion that will focus on these interfaces to understand the origins of their unique properties. The project will determine how these interfaces deform differently than the surrounding materials and how the interfacial deformation can be designed to yield materials with improved performance. The research team will engage high school and undergraduate students in an integrated research experience spanning the University of Akron and Princeton University, accelerating the understanding and discovery of new materials while broadening the U.S. technology workforce.

This project aims to 1) establish a mechanistic understanding of gradients in nanoscale rheological properties at polymer/polymer interfaces and their connection to molecular structure, and 2) pioneer a new strategy for the rational control of rheology and mechanics near polymer/polymer interfaces via the introduction of nanoparticle surfactants. A central challenge in accomplishing these goals has been a longstanding inability to resolve directly nanoscale gradients in rheological response near soft interfaces. This research will overcome this challenge via a feedback loop between high-throughput molecular dynamics simulations (Simmons) and experiments (Priestley). Experiments will combine layer-resolved fluorescence spectroscopy with a novel non-contact shear rheology method that enables nanoscale resolution of gradients in rheological properties near polymer interfaces. Simulations will incorporate high-speed coarse-grained simulations and chemically-realistic all-atom simulations. By systematically probing a matrix of polymer and interfacial properties, simulations and experiments will interconnect interfacial thermodynamics, segmental dynamics, and rheological response near polymer/polymer interfaces. These results will be combined with a matrix of simulations and experiments probing the effect of nanoparticle surfactants on interfacial deformation to establish a new mechanism-based strategy for control of interfacial rheological response via the targeted introduction of nanoparticle surfactants. Ultimately, results from this work will accelerate design of materials with targeted interfacial properties and deformation, enabling new nanostructured polymers for applications ranging from next-generation batteries to separations membranes to lightweight structural materials. In addition to engagement of students over a range of levels in a cross-institution training program, the PI's will extend the impact of this research through joint organization of a symposium at a national meeting focused on bridging polymer and interfacial phenomena research communities.

por.por_cntn:
Many of the most promising emerging materials for new technologies are "nanomaterials'", with external dimensions or internal structure only hundreds of atoms across. Examples include durable lightweight composites used in structural applications, next-generation battery materials with the potential to enable safer energy storage, and films employed in chemical separations and water purification. These materials' immense promise is a result of the fact that they are 'more than the sum of their parts'. The interfaces between domains in these materials take on properties that can differ from any of the materials' constituents, and this "interphase" so pervades these materials that it can dominate their properties.

At the same time, the properties of this interphase have been poorly understood and the subject of immense research for at least 35 years. Perhaps the most challenging and practically important aspects of this problem are the questions of how molecular motion, flow, and mechanical properties are altered in this interphase. These changes control some of the most important performance properties of nanomaterials: their rigidity and toughness in structural applications; their permeability when used to separate distinct chemicals or to carry the ions that power battery function; and their ability to be processed and manufactured. As a consequence of this inability to fully understand or predict understand their properties, nanomaterials have yet to realize their full potential. 

This project has established new fundamental understanding of why and how the molecular motion, flow, and mechanical behavior of nanomaterials are altered in the interphase that controls the properties of so many emerging materials. 

Fundamentally, results (published in journals including The Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences) have provided new insight into why these properties are changed in the interphase, suggesting that they result from a combination of changes in the amount of space molecules have to 'rattle around' near interfaces and from differences in material stiffness across the interface. This deep understanding suggests new ways to predict these changes and guide their design. Results have also provided the first full nanoscale picture of these changes, including how they are lost with increasing distance from an interface and how far they extend from the interface. Practically, these findings help guide the choice of how much interface is needed in a particular material to yield desired properties. Findings also have provided new insight into how the interphase changes as a material is heated or cooled - key guidance on the question of the temperature range over which these materials can be usefully applied. 

Results of this project published in the Journal Nature have answered the key question of how and why the interphase leads to changes in flow and mechanical response of polymers - large molecules that are one of the most important classes of materials. This work established a new theory that predicts these changes, capturing two effects - at the surface of a polymer, molecules move faster, but at the same time these large molecules dip down deeper into the material, acting like 'anchors'. This phenomenon causes the surfaces of polymers act uniquely rubbery. This finding has major implications for how polymer surfaces stick to one another, including in adhesives, coatings, and advanced and 3D manufacturing methods. 

Collectively, the scientific findings from this project thus will accelerate the development of new nanostructured materials with improved properties needed to enable advances in clean energy, in tough lightweight materials, in improved coatings, and in lower-energy separations processes.

In parallel, this project has contributed to broadening the science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) workforce through multiple education and outreach activities. The project led to development, in collaboration with the University of South Florida College ReachOut Program (CROP), of a summer workshop on scientific computing, which engaged high school students from diverse backgrounds in a training experience spanning from foundational programming skills to development of their own scientific simulation codes. This activity aimed to address a major structural barrier to diverse participation in the STEM workforce - the prevalence of unpaid STEM internships and enrichment activities that are not practically accessible to students who cannot afford unpaid work. In response, this paid experience offered an opportunity for high school students to engage in a STEM experience that exposed them to key elements of computational science and strengthened their skills, resumes, qualifications, and professional networks - key enabling tools for success in progressing to a STEM-related career.

Beyond this new workshop, the project also engaged undergraduate students in research internships, further exposing a diverse set of students to scientific practice and concepts. Furthermore, the project team worked with a local high-school teacher, who engaged in a summer research experience in the PI's research group, to develop a software module for hands-on experience with scientific computer simulation in the classroom. Use of this module was piloted in a local high school class.
